Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Flexible Networks with Source Control

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Novel technologies such as software defined networking are changing the networking landscape by giving individual domains (such as ISPs) flexible control over their routers' behavior. Yet the Internet's interdomain routing architecture, which requires coordination among domains, remains mired in inflexibility. Indeed, many of the key shortcomings of the Internet's architecture --- including unreliability, inefficient resource allocation, and insecurity --- can be attributed in large part to inflexible routing. The Internet's BGP and IP protocols offer only a single path to each destination, and this path may be broken, inefficient, or insecure.

This project is developing an approach to bring flexibility to the Internet's routing and forwarding architecture. To break through the current logjam of inflexible routing, the project is advancing source-controlled routing (SCR) as an architectural approach to enable fundamentally more flexible routing. Rather than embedding the routing decisions within the network, routing decisions are a parameter to the network chosen at the source, i.e., the user's device or one acting on its behalf. That flexibility yields solutions to multiple problems, including reliability, performance, and protection from certain traffic attraction attacks.

To achieve a viable SCR architecture, the project is solving three key challenges: policy flexibility of the core architecture; security; and scalability. First, while past SCR architectures gave route control to users, they took away control from network owners and operators. The key need is "policy flexibility" in the architecture, to enable SCR without limiting network owners' control. The project is developing a formal theory of policy flexibility and designing an architecture which achieves high policy flexibility. Second, the project is quantifying the vulnerability of SCR architectures to denial-of-service attacks and developing techniques to limit the worst-case damage attackers can inflict. Third, the project is developing techniques for sources to utilize flexible routing in a scalable way, improving latency and reliability of Internet communications.

Broader Impact.The result of this project will be the theoretical foundations, design, and implementation of an Internet architecture that offers significant gains to areas which are the most critical challenges for the Internet today --- including reliability, performance, and security. The project's theoretically-grounded research methodology, including a novel theory of protocol flexibility, will be integrated with education via development of material for a graduate-level "Theory of Computer Networks" course and survey papers. Results will be disseminated through publications, presentations, and a public software release.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed techniques to significantly improve data transport performance, including both latency and throughput, across the wide-area Internet.

First, as an architectural building block, the project developed an approach to bring flexibility to the Internet's routing and forwarding architecture. To break through the current logjam of inflexible routing, the project advanced source-controlled routing (SCR) as an architectural approach to enable fundamentally more flexible routing. In this approach, rather than embedding the routing decisions within the network, routing decisions are a parameter to the network chosen at the source, i.e., the user's device or one acting on its behalf. That flexibility yields solutions to multiple problems, including reliability, performance, and protection from certain traffic attraction attacks. The project solved several key challenges to achieve and utilize a viable SCR architecture. One challenge is security; the project quantified the the vulnerability of SCR architectures to denial-of-service attacks. Next, the project developed techniques for sources to utilize flexible routing in a scalable way -- specifically by using simultaneous data transmission along multiple paths to substantially improve end-to-end latency, particularly in cases where latency is otherwise highly variable or unreliable. This approach was also shown to be applicable to reduce query latency in cloud computing services and domain name system (DNS) queries which are essential to Internet architecture.

Second, the project explored the question of how generally to improve latency in the Internet end-to-end, tackling in particular the challenge of achieving latency as close as possible to the speed of light. The project performed measurements of latency inflation in the current Internet infrastructure, identifying that typically loading just the text of a web page requires roughly 34 times the speed of light round-trip time between the client and server (and more in many cases). The project performed large-scale measurements that broke down this inflation into its constituent causes, which included  infrastructure and transport-layer factors. Based on this, the project developed designs for a near-speed-of-light Internet infrastructure spanning the United States, suggesting that reducing infrastructure latencies by 3x may be surprisingly affordable.

Third, the project developed transport-layer improvements to wide-area performance. To reduce transport latency in short flows (including most web flows), the project developed a protocol that judiciously accelerates the startup phase while ameliorating the resulting risk of packet loss if the initial startup phase sends data too aggressively. To improve performance of medium and long-length flows, the project developed a novel transport architecture, Performance-oriented Congestion Control (PCC), that utilizes online learning to optimize a performance objective.  The resulting protocol is in many cases 10x faster than TCP and produces more consistent, resilient behavior.

Finally, the project pursued educational and outreach activities. Most significantly, the project developed a freely-available online course, "Cloud Networking", which covers modern approaches to building hyperscale cloud data center networks and the wide-area connectivity that supports those data centers. To date, tens of thousands of individuals have enrolled in the course. In addition, the project presented several short modules to pre-college students, and disseminated research results through publications and open-source release of code and data, including code of the PCC project and an Internet latency measurement data set.
